description: Tomato is a popular fruit (often treated as a vegetable) grown widely in India. Rich in vitamins A, C, K, and potassium, it's used in culinary dishes like curries, sauces, and salads.

soil.type: Well-drained, loamy soil with organic matter

climate.watering: Water regularly at the base of the plant. Avoid water logging and overhead watering.

symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit that may merge to form larger lesions
Leaf yellowing and eventual defoliation, reducing photosynthesis
Scabby lesions on fruit affecting its quality and marketability

background.cause: Bacterial infection by *Xanthomonas campestris*, which enters through natural openings or wounds.
background.spread_by: Contaminated seeds, soil, water, rain splash, overhead irrigation, and human contact.

cure: Use copper-based bactericides to reduce disease severity, but complete elimination is not possible.
Prune affected leaves and branches to limit bacterial spread.
Sterilize garden tools regularly to prevent spreading bacteria from one plant to another.
Apply bactericides early in the morning or late evening to avoid sun damage to plants.
Remove severely infected plants to prevent the disease from spreading to healthy plants.
diseases.fertilizers: Apply phosphorus-rich fertilizers to support root growth and fruit development.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds to avoid initial infection.
Avoid overhead irrigation to prevent water splashing, which can spread the bacteria.
Rotate crops every 3 years to break the bacterial lifecycle in the soil.
Plant resistant varieties if available for your region.
Improve garden hygiene by removing plant debris and weeds that can harbor bacteria.
Install drip irrigation systems to water plants at their base, reducing leaf moisture.

symptoms: Dark concentric rings on older leaves, often surrounded by a yellow halo
Yellowing of leaves around the spots, leading to defoliation
Fruit rot and defoliation affecting plant health and yield

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Alternaria solani*, which thrives in warm, humid conditions.
background.spread_by: Contaminated soil or plant debris, wind, and rain.

cure: Remove and destroy infected plants to limit the spread of the fungus.
Apply fungicides such as Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil as soon as symptoms appear.
Use organic fungicide sprays such as neem oil for early infections.
Water plants at the base and avoid wetting the foliage to limit fungal growth.
Fungicides should be reapplied after rainfall for effective control.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers with nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium (NPK) ratios like 10-10-10 or 12-24-12.
prevention: Space plants adequately to ensure good air circulation and reduce humidity.
Water plants early in the day to allow leaves to dry before nightfall.
Apply mulch around the base of plants to prevent soil-borne fungal spores from splashing onto leaves.
Remove weeds and other debris where fungi can thrive.
Use disease-resistant tomato varieties if available.
Monitor plants regularly and remove any infected leaves as soon as symptoms are noticed.

symptoms: Dark, water-soaked spots on leaves, stems, and fruits, often leading to rapid collapse.

Plant collapse and rapid deterioration of health.

background.cause: Fungus-like pathogen *Phytophthora infestans*, which thrives in cool, wet weather.

cure: Apply systemic fungicides such as Metalaxyl or Mancozeb at the first signs of infection.
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to stop the disease from spreading.
Use fungicidal sprays regularly during cool and wet periods to prevent new infections.
Disinfect gardening tools and equipment after working with infected plants.
Dispose of plant debris far from your garden to avoid fungal spread.

prevention: Use tomato varieties bred for late blight resistance.
Ensure good air circulation by properly spacing plants and pruning excess foliage.
Avoid planting tomatoes in areas with poor drainage to prevent water buildup.
Rotate crops yearly and avoid planting tomatoes or potatoes in the same spot consecutively.
Monitor weather conditions and apply preventative fungicide sprays during cool, wet periods.
Water plants early in the day to reduce moisture levels on leaves.

symptoms: Yellow patches on the upper leaf surface.
Olive-green mold growth on the undersides of leaves.
Leaf drop and reduced fruit yield due to compromised plant health.
